questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 6-month history of mild episodic abdominal pain. The episodes occur every 1-2 months and last for a few hours. The pain is located in the epigastrium, radiates to his back, and is occasionally associated with mild nausea. His mother is concerned that his condition might be hereditary because his older sister was diagnosed with congenital heart disease. He is otherwise healthy and has met all developmental milestones. He is at the 75th percentile for height and the 65th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no abdominal distention, guarding, or rebound tenderness. Which of the following congenital conditions would best explain this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pancreatic divisum The patient has findings of recurrent acute pancreatitis. Pancreas divisum is a congenital malformation that is caused by a failure of fusion of the ventral and dorsal pancreatic ducts, which normally join at 8 weeks of gestation. Pancreas divisum is present in about 10% of the population and is usually asymptomatic, but a minority of cases can develop chronic abdominal pain or recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis, as seen here. Pancreas divisum can be diagnosed by endoscopic ultrasonography or MRCP, which would show a ventral pancreatic duct that drains along with the common bile duct into the major duodenal papilla and a dorsal pancreatic duct that drains separately into the duodenum via the minor duodenal papilla.

Highyeild:

Pancreatic divisum Pancreatic divisum is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas, caused by the failure of dorsal and ventral ducts to fuse during fetal development. There are three types of pancreas divisum based on the degree of fusion between the ducts. All types of pancreas divisum have a dominant dorsal duct and pancreatic secretions flow through the accessory papilla. MRCP is often used for diagnosis, but ERCP is the gold standard of investigation . Operative dorsal duct sphincterotomy , with or without sphincteroplasty, is the preferred surgical treatment. Endoscopic therapy is recommended for patients with pancreas divisum and acute recurrent pancreatitis , but it may not be as effective for those with chronic pancreatitis or chronic pain.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Duodenal atresia manifests within the first 1–2 days of life with delayed meconium passage, vomiting, epigastric distention, and a scaphoid lower abdomen. Recurrent epigastric pain in a 6-year-old patient is not consistent with this diagnosis Option: B. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis typically manifests with postprandial, nonbilious projectile vomiting, visible epigastric peristaltic waves, and a palpable olive-shaped structure in the epigastrium within the first few weeks of life. Recurrent epigastric pain in a 6-year-old patient is not consistent with this diagnosis. Option: C. A biliary cyst can cause recurrent acute pancreatitis during childhood as a result of pancreatic duct obstruction and pancreaticobiliary reflux. However, patients with pancreatitis due to a biliary cyst would also have obstructive jaundice and a palpable right hypochondrial mass, which are not present here. A different diagnosis is more likely in this patient.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of intermittent epigastric discomfort. He reports that his urine has been very dark, and his stools have been pale for the past week. His appetite has decreased, and he has had a 4.5-kg weight loss during this period. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He drinks a few shots of vodka daily. He has no history of severe illness. He has chronic left knee pain, for which he takes acetaminophen. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and scleral icterus. There are scratch marks on the extremities. Abdominal examination shows a non-tender, palpable mass in the right upper quadrant. The remainder of the examination is normal. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 11.6 g/dL Bilirubin Total 6 mg/dL Direct 5.2 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase 220 IU/L Ultrasonography shows dilated extrahepatic and pancreatic ducts and a distended gall bladder. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Malignant biliary tract obstruction Painless jaundice, together with a palpable gallbladder, should always raise suspicion for pancreatic malignancy . This patient's smoking history is a risk factor for pancreatic adenocarcinoma, which manifests with biliary tract obstruction as a late sign of infiltrative disease. Dilated biliary and pancreatic ducts (the double duct sign) can be seen on ultrasonography as a result of a stenosing tumor in the pancreatic head and subsequent prestenotic dilation, as seen in this patient. Direct hyperbilirubinemia indicates obstructive jaundice. The accumulation of serum bile acids, which causes pruritus, could explain the scratch marks on this patient's extremities. His significant weight loss is another classic symptom of a malignant process.

Highyeild:

Carcinoma Pancreas is a type of cancer that originates in the pancreas, with the most common type being pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). The majority of PDAC cases occur in the head of the pancreas, with a smaller percentage occurring in the body and tail. Jaundice caused by obstruction of the distal bile duct is a common symptom of ampullary and pancreatic head tumors. Other symptoms that may occur with jaundice include pruritus, dark urine, pale stools, and steatorrhea. In the absence of jaundice, symptoms are usually nonspecific, such as vague discomfort, anorexia, and weight loss, which are often overlooked by patients and doctors. Back pain is a concerning symptom, as it suggests the possibility of retroperitoneal infiltration. Other signs of intra-abdominal malignancy, such as a palpable mass, ascites, supraclavicular nodes, and tumor deposits in the pelvis, indicate a poor prognosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Patients with late-stage alcoholic liver disease often develop manifestations of liver failure, such as jaundice. However, laboratory studies show indirect hyperbilirubinemia. Other possible findings include hypoalbuminemia and subsequent ascites. Abdominal examination shows hepatomegaly or a cirrhotic liver. The double duct sign (which indicates biliary and pancreatic duct obstruction) is not present in patients with alcoholic liver disease. Option: C. Acute acetaminophen-induced liver injury is caused by ingestion of toxic amounts of the drug (> 4000 mg/day). As a result of hepatocellular toxicity, patients manifest with acute, fulminant liver failure (nausea, vomiting, jaundice, coagulation disturbance, encephalopathy, and highly elevated transaminases), which is most severe within 96 hours of ingestion. Subacute onset of jaundice, weight loss, double duct sign (dilated biliary and pancreatic ducts), and lack of encephalopathy are all inconsistent with acute acetaminophen toxicity. Option: D. Patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis can develop cholestatic jaundice as a result of bile duct fibrosis. On ERCP, the bile duct typically has a beaded appearance, which indicates strictures alternating with dilated segments of the duct. However, this patient has a double duct sign (dilated biliary and pancreatic ducts) on ultrasonography, which indicates a localized obstruction at a level proximal to the major duodenal papilla.

Extraedge:

During an examination, physicians should look for signs of jaundice, weight loss, a palpable liver, and a palpable gallbladder. Courvoisier first noticed the association between an enlarged gallbladder and pancreatic tumors in 1890. Patients with a recent diabetes diagnosis and upper abdominal symptoms, especially those above 50 years of age with no family history or obesity, should be suspected of having pancreatic tumors. Unexplained pancreatitis may also be a sign of tumors and should be followed up with imaging. Tumors of the body and tail of the pancreas often grow silently and may present at an advanced, unresectable stage.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is referred to the general surgical clinic with a 4-week history of epigastric discomfort and fullness. He reports occasional episodes of vomiting and early satiety. He has a previous history of alcohol abuse and was discharged from the hospital 2 months previously, following treatment for acute pancreatitis. On examination, he appears clinically well, with a soft abdomen and mild epigastric tenderness and fullness. Preliminary investigations reveal a normal full blood count and biochemistry, with a serum amylase of 100 IU. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pancreatic pseudocyst The presentation of this patient is most consistent with a diagnosis of pseudocyst of the pancreas. A pancreatic pseudocyst is defined as a localized collection of pancreatic secretions, usually rich in digestive enzymes, that is enclosed by a non-epithelialized wall and persists for more than 4 weeks. Treatment is either conservative or drainage of the pseudocyst.

Highyeild:

Pseudocysts are a chronic collection of pancreatic fluid surrounded by fibrosis and granulation tissue. They account for 75% of cystic lesions of the pancreas and are commonly located in the lesser sac or within the substance of the gland. Pseudocysts can occur after acute or chronic pancreatitis, with alcohol being the most common cause. Symptoms include abdominal pain, early satiety, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, and fever. Diagnosis is made with a CT scan of the abdomen, and treatment depends on the size and age of the pseudocyst, with drainage indicated for those larger than 5 cm. Pseudocyst complications include infection (14% most common), duodenal obstruction, pain due to expansion, rupture, hemorrhage (up to 10%), and abscess.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Acute pancreatitis - The common presentations include central abdominal pain that starts at a low intensity and gradually increases in severity. The pain may radiate to the back, may be associated with nausea and vomiting, and may be improved by sitting forward. Option: C . Pancreatic cancer - Jaundice secondary to obstruction of the distal bile duct is the most common symptom that draws attention to ampullary or pancreatic head tumors. It is characteristically painless jaundice but may be associated with Nausea or epigastric discomfort. Option: D. Crohn's disease - Crohn’s disease commonly presents with features of chronicity. Characterized by colicky abdominal pain which is postprandial. Serum amylase ll not rise in this.

Extraedge:

Pseudocysts communicate with the pancreatic ductal system in up to 80% of cases, so external drainage creates a pathway for pancreatic duct leakage to and through the catheter exit site. Internal drainage methods include percutaneous catheter-based methods, endoscopic methods, and surgical methods. Surgical options include cystogastrostomy, Roux-en-Y cystojejunostomy, and cystoduodenostomy. The preferred modality is internal drainage of the cyst by cystojejunostomy , which has a slightly lower recurrence rate but is associated with significantly more blood loss and operative time.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of abdominal bloating and increased frequency of stools. He describes the stools as bulky, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush. He also has a 4-month history of recurrent dull upper abdominal pain that usually lasts for a few days, worsens after meals, and is not relieved with antacids. He has had a 10-kg weight loss in the past 4 months. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 37 years. He has a 12-year history of drinking 6 to 8 beers daily. He is 160 cm tall and weighs 52 kg; his BMI is 20 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows mild epigastric tenderness without rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ERCP ERCP is the most sensitive and specific test for chronic pancreatitis (CP), even in the early stages of the disease. Typical features of CP on ERCP include pancreatic ductal dilation, ductal strictures, and intra-ductal calcification.

Highyeild:

Chronic pancreatitis is characterized by persistent inflammation and irreversible fibrosis, which leads to the atrophy of pancreatic parenchyma. Associated with chronic pain and endocrine and exocrine insufficiency Exocrine insufficiency precedes endocrine insufficiency by many years and is more closely related to morphologic changes Approximately 90% of beta cell mass must be lost before clinical diabetes develops Classification of various causes based on the TIGAR-O system Diagnosis: X-ray abdomen shows diffuse pancreatic calcification in 30-40% of cases CT scan shows dilated pancreatic duct (68%), parenchymal atrophy (54%), and pancreatic calcifications (50%) MRI detects changes in the pancreatic parenchyma suggestive of chronic inflammation MRCP with secretin injection evaluates intraductal strictures and pancreatic duct disruption ERCP is considered the gold standard for diagnosis , but the advent of secretin MRCP and EUS has decreased its role EUS is the most accurate technique to diagnose CP in early stages Rosemont criteria provide EUS criteria for diagnosis Measurement of fecal elastase-1 level is preferred noninvasive study to diagnose pancreatic exocrine insufficiency Steatorrhea occurs if stool fat content exceeds 7 gm/day Treatment: Encourage patients to stop drinking and smoking NSAIDs are first-line treatment, for severe pain treated with potent long-acting narcotics Pancreatic enzyme replacement is recommended for pancreatic exocrine insufficiency ERCP primary modality for treating symptomatic pancreatic duct obstruction Endoscopic stone extraction is considered for pain and pancreatic duct dilation secondary to stones Patients with dilated pancreatic ducts (diameter >7 mm) require a decompressing procedure , and those with normal pancreatic ducts require the resectional procedure

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Measurement of baseline levels of the tumor marker CA 19-9 is not indicated for chronic pancreatitis but in patients who are diagnosed with pancreatic cancer to monitor disease progression and response to therapy (i.e., CA 19-9 is a prognostic indicator). In patients with a pancreatic lesion on imaging, serum CA 19-9 levels may help differentiate between a malignant (CA 19-9 would be elevated) and a benign lesion. However, CA 19-9 is not an appropriate initial test because it is neither sensitive (may be normal in small pancreatic cancers) nor specific (is elevated in other abdominal malignancies and a few benign conditions) for pancreatic cancer. Option: B. An abdominal ultrasound (AUS) can be used to detect late findings of chronic pancreatitis including pancreatic ductal calcifications and/or ductal irregularity/dilation, which are pathognomonic features of chronic pancreatitis (CP), as well as pancreatic pseudocysts, a common complication. However, an AUS is not a sensitive imaging modality for the pancreas because it is a retroperitoneal organ that is not easily visualized through the overlying bowel loops. An unremarkable AUS exam in a patient with suspected CP does not rule out the diagnosis. A different test is recommended as the initial test for suspected CP. Option: C. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is useful to diagnose a pathology in the upper gastrointestinal tract (e.g., peptic ulcer disease, GERD, malignancy) that may present with recurrent upper abdominal pain and weight loss, as seen in this patient. However, these symptoms in conjunction with steatorrhea and chronic alcohol abuse, make chronic pancreatitis (CP) more likely. Steatorrhea occurs in chronic pancreatitis due to a deficiency of pancreatic lipase. Upper GI endoscopy cannot visualize the pancreas and is not a recommended diagnostic tool for CP.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 2-hour history of severe epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting. Her father has a history of similar episodes of abdominal pain and developed diabetes mellitus at the age of 30 years. Abdominal examination shows guarding and rigidity. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows a diffuse enlargement of the pancreas; no gallstones are visualized. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Premature activation of trypsinogen The patient's findings are suggestive of acute pancreatitis which usually occurs in older patients. The typical age of presentation and the family history of similar episodes suggests a hereditary component of the disease. Premature activation of trypsinogen to trypsin within the pancreas activates the pancreatic digestive enzymes (lipase, amylase, and protease) that cause pancreatic autodigestion and inflammation. This enzymatic pathway is the underlying pathophysiology of acute pancreatitis, regardless of the etiology (e.g., pancreatic ductal blockage in gallstone pancreatitis, pancreatic acinar injury in alcohol-induced pancreatitis). Hereditary pancreatitis , which this patient most likely has, is usually caused by a mutated PRSS1 gene that promotes intrapancreatic trypsinogen activation.

Highyeild:

Acute pancreatitis (AP) is mild and self-limited in most patients, but 10-20% of patients may experience a rapidly progressive inflammatory response associated with a prolonged hospital stay, significant morbidity, and mortality. Severe pancreatitis has a mortality rate of 10-30% and is often caused by multiorgan dysfunction syndrome and septic complications. AP results from abnormal pancreatic enzyme activation , leading to autodigestion of pancreatic tissue and triggering an inflammatory response. Gallstones and ethanol abuse are the most common risk factors for AP. Clinical features include: epigastric pain, nausea/vomiting, and dehydration; severe cases may exhibit abdominal distention and rebound tenderness. Diagnosis is based on clinical findings and elevated pancreatic enzyme levels, with lipase being a more specific marker than amylase. Treatment involves aggressive fluid resuscitation, analgesics, and enteral nutrition.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Defective glucuronidation of bilirubin is seen in Gilbert syndrome and Crigler-Najjar syndrome, which are genetic disorders characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes to the development of black or brown pigment gallstones, which are a risk factor for acute pancreatitis. However, this patient has no history of recurrent episodes of jaundice and there are no gallstones visualized on abdominal ultrasonography. Option: B. Elevated serum amylase levels greater than three times the baseline in a patient with acute epigastric pain is diagnostic of acute pancreatitis. Amylase is an intracellular enzyme, and elevated serum levels indicate pancreatic acinar injury. Hyperamylasemia is, therefore, a result of acute pancreatitis, not a cause of it. Option: C. Increased β-glucuronidase activity is a result of bacterial infections of the biliary tract. β-glucuronidase deconjugates direct bilirubin, resulting in excessive unconjugated bilirubin in the biliary tract that precipitates with calcium to form brown pigment gallstones. This can cause acute pancreatitis. However, gallstone pancreatitis would typically manifest in older individuals (> 40 years of age). Moreover, there are no gallstones visualized on the abdominal ultrasonography of this patient.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting that began an hour after she finished lunch. Examination shows abdominal guarding and rigidity; bowel sounds are reduced. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography shows the dorsal pancreatic duct draining into the minor papilla and a separate smaller duct draining into the major papilla. The spleen is located anterior to the left kidney. A disruption of which of the following embryological processes is the most likely cause of this patient's imaging findings?

options.label: B
options.text: Fusion of visceral and parietal peritoneum

options.label: D
options.text: Proliferation of mesenchyma in the dorsal mesentery

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fusion of pancreatic buds Fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds normally occurs during the 8th week of embryological development. Subsequently, the distal portion of the dorsal pancreatic duct fuses with the ventral pancreatic duct, which drains into the major duodenal papilla via the Ampulla of Vater. The proximal portion of the dorsal pancreatic duct would degenerate or persist as an accessory pancreatic duct that drains into the minor duodenal papilla . If the pancreatic buds fail to fuse (pancreas divisum), the dorsal and ventral pancreatic ducts would drain separately into the duodenum with the dorsal pancreatic duct draining via the minor duodenal papilla, as seen on this patient's MRCP. Most individuals with pancreas divisum are asymptomatic, but a small percentage will present with chronic abdominal pain or pancreatitis, as is the case here.

Highyeild:

Pancreatic divisum Pancreatic divisum is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas, caused by the failure of dorsal and ventral ducts to fuse during fetal development. There are three types of pancreas divisum based on the degree of fusion between the ducts. All types of pancreas divisum have a dominant dorsal duct and pancreatic secretions flow through the accessory papilla. MRCP is often used for diagnosis, but ERCP is the gold standard of investigation . Operative dorsal duct sphincterotomy , with or without sphincteroplasty, is the preferred surgical treatment. Endoscopic therapy is recommended for patients with pancreas divisum and acute recurrent pancreatitis , but it may not be as effective for those with chronic pancreatitis or chronic pain.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Fusion of the visceral and parietal peritoneum ensures that the pancreas becomes a retroperitoneal structure (secondary retroperitonealization). In the event that this fusion does not occur, the pancreas may remain intraperitoneal. This anomaly is not known to cause any clinical signs or symptoms. Option: C. Rotation of the midgut is important for proper positioning of the intestines. In cases of malrotation, the formation of fibrous bands (Ladd bands) may lead to volvulus or acute intestinal obstruction. Imaging typically shows small bowel sequestered on the right side of the abdomen and large bowel on the left. Anomalies of the pancreatic duct would not be explained by this diagnosis. Option: D. The proliferation of mesenchyme in the dorsal mesentery is the process by which the spleen develops. This patient's spleen is situated in the normal anatomical position (anterior to the left kidney) and does not have congenital abnormalities that are evident on imaging.

questions.text: 6 days after undergoing pancreaticoduodenectomy for pancreatic cancer, a 45-year-old woman has 2 episodes of non-bilious vomiting and mild epigastric pain. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. She drinks 3–4 beers daily. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), her pulse is 98/min, and her blood pressure is 116/82 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Examination shows a midline surgical incision over the abdomen with minimal serous discharge and no erythema. The abdomen is soft with mild tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 11.6 g/dL Leukocyte count 16,000/mm3 Serum Na+ 133 mEq/L K+ 3.4 mEq/L Cl- 115 mEq/L Arterial blood gas on room air shows: pH 7.20 pCO2 23 mm Hg pO2 91 mm Hg HCO3- 10 mEq/L Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's acid-base status?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fistula Pancreatic fistula is a complication of pancreatic surgery that presents with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis , which is caused by the loss of bicarbonate-rich pancreatic fluids . Most pancreatic fistulas resolve with conservative treatment (e.g., octreotide, parenteral nutrition) or with stenting of the pancreatic duct.

Highyeild:

Pancreatic fistula Pancreatic fistula is caused by operative trauma or pancreatitis. The site of the fistula and its communication must be identified. Amylase content can diagnose pancreatic juice leakage. Pancreatic fistula is classified as low output (<200 mL/day) or high output (>200 mL/day). Factors affecting the outcome of pancreatic anastomosis include the texture of the pancreatic remnant, the caliber of the main pancreatic duct, exocrine pancreatic juice output, and surgical technique. A soft pancreas has a higher risk of anastomotic failure compared to a firm or hard pancreas. Decreased juice output is associated with a lowered risk of anastomotic failure. End-to-side pancreaticojejunostomy is the preferred surgical technique. Most cases of pancreatic fistula resolve spontaneously with conservative treatment. Prophylactic octreotide may be beneficial in preventing pancreatic fistula. The role of octreotide once a fistula is established is unclear.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Primary adrenal insufficiency can cause normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, but this patient has no clear risk factors for adrenal dysfunction (e.g., chronic glucocorticoid use). Additionally, patients with adrenal insufficiency typically present with hyperkalemia (due to mineralocorticoid deficiency) and hypotension, neither of which are seen in this patient. Option: B. Excessive alcohol intake may lead to alcoholic ketoacidosis, which usually occurs in malnourished patients and causes elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis. While this patient drinks excessively, she has a normal anion gap. Additionally, alcoholic ketoacidosis typically presents after an episode of binge drinking with little or no food intake and persistent vomiting, which is not consistent with this patient's history. Option: C. Rhabdomyolysis usually presents with myalgia, generalized weakness, and myoglobinuria. It may cause elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis (due to the breakdown of muscular tissue and the resulting release of lactic acid from myocytes). This patient is hospitalized and just underwent surgery, both of which increase the risk of rhabdomyolysis. However, she does not show any signs of myalgia or weakness, has a normal anion gap, and is borderline hypokalemic, none of which is consistent with rhabdomyolysis.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of abdominal pain and vomiting. Initially, the vomitus was food that he had recently eaten, but it is now bilious. He has had similar complaints several times in the past 6 years. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years and drinks 18 oz of whiskey daily. He is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 48 kg; his BMI is 19 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an epigastric mass. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pancreatic pseudocyst A pancreatic pseudocyst, which is a complication of acute or chronic pancreatitis , is caused by leakage of pancreatic exocrine secretions from damaged ducts. This patient's history of recurrent epigastric pain, vomiting, and chronic alcohol consumption makes a diagnosis of pancreatitis highly likely. Patients with chronic pancreatitis and heavy alcohol use are often cachectic due to malnutrition . Pancreatic pseudocysts, when large enough, can manifest with a palpable epigastric mass and bilious vomiting (due to extrinsic compression of the distal duodenum) or non-bilious vomiting (due to gastric outlet obstruction). The diagnosis can be confirmed by imaging; a well-defined fluid collection would be seen in the vicinity of the pancreas.

Highyeild:

Pancreatic pseudocyst Pseudocysts are a chronic collection of pancreatic fluid surrounded by fibrosis and granulation tissue. They account for 75% of cystic lesions of the pancreas and are commonly located in the lesser sac or within the substance of the gland. Pseudocysts can occur after acute or chronic pancreatitis, with alcohol being the most common cause. Symptoms include abdominal pain, early satiety, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, and fever. Diagnosis is made with a CT scan of the abdomen, and treatment depends on the size and age of the pseudocyst, with drainage indicated for those larger than 5 cm. Pseudocyst complications include infection (14% most common), duodenal obstruction, pain due to expansion, rupture, hemorrhage (up to 10%), and abscess.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Chronic cholecystitis is the consequence of recurrent acute cholecystitis. Recurrent episodes of acute cholecystitis, which manifests with upper abdominal pain and bilious or non-bilious vomiting, could explain this patient's medical history. However, in chronic cholecystitis, the gallbladder is fibrosed and shrunken which would not explain this patient's abdominal mass. Option: B. Retroperitoneal fibrosis is a rare condition that can manifest with recurrent abdominal pain (due to hydronephrosis or mesenteric ischemia) and vomiting (due to hydronephrosis and uremia). However, an abdominal mass in retroperitoneal fibrosis is typically due to hydronephrosis and so would be palpable in the flanks, not in the epigastrium. In addition, other typical manifestations of retroperitoneal fibrosis, such as lower limb edema, varicocele, and claudication are absent in this patient. Option: C. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a cause of gastric outlet obstruction (GOO) and manifests with vomiting and a palpable epigastric mass. However, it is a condition of infancy and does not manifest for the first time in adulthood. Moreover, vomitus is characteristically non-bilious, because the level of GOO by the pyloric hypertrophy is above the second part of the duodenum, into which the biliary duct drains.

Extraedge:

Pseudocysts communicate with the pancreatic ductal system in up to 80% of cases, so external drainage creates a pathway for pancreatic duct leakage to and through the catheter exit site. Internal drainage methods include percutaneous catheter-based methods, endoscopic methods, and surgical methods. Surgical options include cystogastrostomy, Roux-en-Y cystojejunostomy, and cystoduodenostomy. The preferred modality is internal drainage of the cyst by cystojejunostomy , which has a slightly lower recurrence rate but is associated with significantly more blood loss and operative time.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of persistent epigastric abdominal pain. She reports dull, aching pain that is worse after meals and wakes her up at night. She is afraid to eat, as it worsens the pain, and has had a 2-kg weight loss during this time. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Her only medication is a calcium supplement. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She appears thin. Examination shows yellow discoloration of the sclera. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a total bilirubin of 9.8 mg/dL, direct bilirubin of 8.6 mg/dL, and an alkaline phosphatase of 120 IU/L. questions.text: A clinical study of patients with the acute abdomen is performed. Those patients with elevated serum lipase are identified. A decrease in which of the following analytes is most likely to predict a worse prognosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Calcium Acute pancreatitis is marked by the release of enzymes that produce chalky areas of fat necrosis, with precipitation of calcium that lowers serum calcium. The worse the inflammation, the lower the calcium level.

Highyeild:

Elevated serum lipase levels are commonly seen in patients with acute pancreatitis, which is an inflammatory condition of the pancreas. In this context, a decrease in serum calcium levels is most likely to predict a worse prognosis. Calcium is an important electrolyte that plays a critical role in many cellular processes, including muscle function, nerve transmission, and blood clotting . In acute pancreatitis, calcium levels may decrease due to a variety of factors, including pancreatic enzyme activation, decreased intestinal absorption, and precipitation of calcium salts in the pancreas. Hypocalcemia is a well-known complication of acute pancreatitis, and it has been associated with increased morbidity and mortality in these patients . Severe hypocalcemia may lead to tetany, seizures, cardiac arrhythmias, and even death. Therefore, prompt correction of hypocalcemia is essential in patients with acute pancreatitis. Albumin, bilirubin, and fibrinogen levels may also be affected in acute pancreatitis, but they are not as closely associated with the prognosis of the disease as calcium.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Hypoalbuminemia is more likely to occur as a complication of chronic pancreatitis with malabsorption. Option: B. Hyperbilirubinemia can occur in cases of gallstone-induced pancreatitis, but the level of bilirubin does not give an indication of the severity of pancreatitis. Option: D. Fibrinogen is an acute phase reactant that increases with inflammation, but does not correlate well with the location or extent of inflammation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old, G2, P1, woman has a screening ultrasound that shows polyhydramnios at 17 weeks gestation. She gives birth at term to a boy who on examination has no abnormal findings. Since birth, he has often vomited after feeding. An infant radiograph with contrast enhancement shows the narrowing of the duodenum. Laboratory studies show sodium, 130 mmol/L; potassium, 3.4 mmol/L; chloride, 85 mmol/L; CO2, 32 mmol/L; glucose, 65 mg/dL; and amylase, 15 U5/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Annular pancreas When the embryologic ventral and dorsal pancreatic buds do not rotate and fuse properly, the duodenum can become encircled by pancreatic tissue, producing an obstruction called the annular pancreas. Depending on the degree of obstruction, this condition may manifest at birth, in childhood, or in adulthood. Polyhydramnios should suggest upper gastrointestinal obstruction in utero.

Highyeild:

The annular pancreas is characterized by a circumferential or near-circumferential band of pancreas tissue that surrounds the second part of the duodenum, typically of ventral pancreas origin and usually proximal to the ampulla. In 40% of cases, duodenal stenosis or atresia can be present at the site of the annulus. The annular pancreas is more common in individuals with Down's syndrome (trisomy 21), occurring in 15-25% of cases. This condition is often associated with other congenital anomalies, such as intestinal malrotation, tracheoesophageal fistula, congenital heart defects, Meckel's diverticulum, and imperforate anus.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A & C. Acute and chronic pancreatitis should be accompanied by abdominal pain and by an elevated serum amylase; they do not generally cause mechanical bowel obstruction, although the inflammation may cause paralytic ileus. Option: D. Neoplasms are focal lesions that may obstruct the biliary tree and pancreatic duct, but generally do not obstruct the duodenum.

Extraedge:

Definitive diagnosis can be made through endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). The treatment of choice is duodenoduodenostomy , which is preferred over duodenojejunostomy due to its lower incidence of postoperative complications, particularly obstruction and blind-loop syndromes.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy has experienced multiple bouts of severe abdominal pain for the past 6 years, but no other medical problems. His father and grandfather have been similarly affected. On examination during the last episode, bowel sounds were absent, and he exhibited marked diffuse abdominal pain with abdominal wall rigidity. A radiograph of the abdomen showed dilated loops of the bowel with air-fluid levels. Laboratory studies showed serum amylase of 3320 U/L. This boy is most likely to have an inherited mutation involving which of the following genes?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PRSS1 This boy has evidence of recurrent pancreatitis, marked by severe abdominal pain, paralytic ileus, and hyperamylasemia. An onset of pancreatitis in children suggests a genetic basis, and the history of an involved parent and grandparent suggests an autosomal dominant mode of transmission. The PRSS1 gene encodes for cationic trypsinogen, which, when mutated, leads to resistance of trypsin to inactivation.

Highyeild:

Chronic pancreatitis can be caused by several factors, including hereditary pancreatitis, cystic fibrosis (CF), infantile malnutrition, and an unexplained idiopathic group. Trypsinogen is normally inhibited and destroyed by SPINK1 if it becomes activated prematurely within the pancreas. Hereditary pancreatitis is an autosomal dominant disorder with an 80% penetrance and is associated with a gain-of-function mutation in the cationic trypsinogen gene (PRSS1) on chromosome 7, which leads to the production of a degradation-resistant form of trypsin. A loss-of-function mutation in SPINK1 is also linked to idiopathic pancreatitis. Some patients with idiopathic chronic pancreatitis have mutations in the CFTR gene. Idiopathic chronic pancreatitis accounts for about 30% of cases and is divided into early-onset and late-onset forms. Patients with hereditary pancreatitis and those who develop pancreatitis at a young age, especially if they smoke tobacco, are at a significantly increased risk of developing pancreatic cancer. Chronic pancreatitis can also be caused by hyperlipidemia and hypercalcemia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. A mutation in the CFTR gene can lead to cystic fibrosis, but there should be pulmonary problems by age 11 years, and bouts of pancreatitis are usually not severe. Option: B. KRAS (an oncogene) is involved with the development of pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Option: D. The SPINK1 gene encodes for a trypsin inhibitor, and mutation can lead to pancreatitis, but the inheritance is autosomal recessive.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a long history of gallbladder disease has a sudden onset of severe midabdominal pain. On physical examination, she has marked abdominal tenderness, particularly in the upper abdomen, and bowel sounds are reduced. An abdominal radiograph shows no free air, but there is marked soft tissue edema. Abdominal CT scan shows decreased attenuation with fluid density involving the pancreas. She is given intravenous fluids and nasogastric suction and recovers gradually. Which of the following serum laboratory tests is most useful for the diagnosis of her disease process?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amylase The clinical features and the preexisting gallbladder disease are highly suggestive of acute pancreatitis. This is confirmed by the appearance of the pancreas on radiologic imaging. The serum amylase as well as serum and urine lipase levels are rapidly elevated after an attack of acute pancreatitis. These enzymes are released from necrotic pancreatic acini. Abnormalities in liver function test results may be seen in cases of gallstone pancreatitis but do not confirm pancreatic involvement.

Highyeild:

Acute pancreatitis (AP) is mild and self-limited in most patients, but 10-20% of patients may experience a rapidly progressive inflammatory response associated with a prolonged hospital stay, significant morbidity, and mortality. Severe pancreatitis has a mortality rate of 10-30% and is often caused by multiorgan dysfunction syndrome and septic complications. AP results from abnormal pancreatic enzyme activation , leading to autodigestion of pancreatic tissue and triggering an inflammatory response. Gallstones and ethanol abuse are the most common risk factors for AP. Clinical features include: epigastric pain, nausea/vomiting, and dehydration; severe cases may exhibit abdominal distention and rebound tenderness. Diagnosis is based on clinical findings and elevated pancreatic enzyme levels, with lipase being a more specific marker than amylase. Treatment involves aggressive fluid resuscitation, analgesics, and enteral nutrition.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . An increased ALT level is more characteristic of liver cell injury. Option: B. Hyperammonemia is a feature of liver failure. Option: C. Although the pancreatic acinar cells can produce bicarbonate, levels of this analyte do not correlate well with pancreatitis.
